fields.description:
A while ago I taught qclone about cloning remote repos+queues. This works if the remote side is structured as

/path/to/repo  # base repo\\
/path/to/repo/.hg/patches  # queue repo

So it would be interesting if Bitbucket could support two things:

a) When creating a patch queue, it would be handy if one could create it into an existing or newly created fork of the base repo. This would allow for qclone, and it would also clearly document the revision the queue is based on.

b) As an option, it might be interesting if Bitbucket would support some form of pushing and popping patches on the queue's base repo. This would be handy to review the actual effect of the patches online. I guess this option would have to be reserved to the queue owner(s).

(I am working on an hg extension, rclone, that supports a similiar idea: http://freehg.org/u/parren/rexec/.)
fields.summary: Make patch queues qclone compatible over SSH (BB-7763)

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

bug in  *{{atlassian-bamboo-elastic-image-6.27.zip}}*

This applies to bamboo-elastic-image agent running in {{{}wrapped mode{}}}. It looks like wrapper is started with respected proper {*}{{JAVA_HOME}}{*}, however the underlying process of agent that wrapper is looking at is not started using {{{*}JAVA_HOME{*}, }}but rather using {{*java* }}command line, which in turns depends in {{*PATH* }}env variable.
The issue can be confirmed on Windows, in terms of linux I don't know if that exists.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Set your JAVA_PATH to whatever supported version by the agent (in my case it was *adoptopenjdk* *8u302*
 # Install adoptopenjdk 8u202 for windows as this version does not work with the agent properly
 # Add to  PATH variable location to the adoptopenjdk 8u202 java bin path as first one. For example PATH=C:\Program Files\\Eclipse Adoptium\jdk-8.0.202.08\bin:....
 # Run agent in wrapped mode

h3. Expected Results

Agent is working properly and reported in bamboo as Idle
h3. Actual Results

Agent is in pending state in bamboo
h3. Workaround

Change PATH variable accordingly, so java command will be the one you want
fields.summary: elastic-bamboo 6.27 wrapper not respecting JAVA_HOME

fields.description:
When running a build in a container image using the runner images, there is no way to tell from the running build if it running in a container and if so, what the image name and/or tag is.

The expectation would be that variables like the following are then expose by Bamboo:

stage.\{id | name}.agent.environment = docker|bambooagent
stage.\{id | name}.agent.docker.image = docker image

 

The value for \{id | name} I'm unsure off, but I suppose this could be optional.

 

This would make huge difference to us as we would then be able to very easily report on whether a build is running in a container of not and also what containers. It would as an example help us react to issues relating to a particular image as we will be able to very easily track what success/error rates look like for a particular image. Currently, it is not possible for us to track this.
fields.summary: Runner image in use as variable

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently the [CustomBuildProcessor|https://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-bamboo/8.1.1/com/atlassian/bamboo/build/CustomBuildProcessor.html] interface only works for build plans and not for deployments. This allows to add additional custom build processes after the main builder runs. However, this does not work for deployments.

h3. Suggested Solution

Extend this one or create a new interface that would allow to create custom plug ins that would run actions after a deployment has run.

h3. Workaround

There is no workaround.
fields.summary: Extend the CustomBuildProcessor to work with deployments

fields.description:
*Summary*

In a Specs managed plan, Bamboo updates plan configuration when changes are made to the Specs file.

There are cases where a commit contains changes to both the spec file and the managed repository i.e
 # commit contains both repository change and specs configuration changes
 # the commit build is expected to run using the updated specs configuration 

In cases when the build is fired before the specs configuration change updates the build plan, the build run using the old build configuration.

*Suggestion*
 # When a plan is managed by Specs, Bamboo should check that the commit contains Specs update, and if it does, a option to only run the build after the Specs configuration is updated may be provided
fields.summary: Specs managed plans build condition

fields.description:
h3. Problem Statement
When file in repository is larger than system RAM Git LFS bug causes system OOM errors. 

h3. Summary

h3. Research Done
[lfs Pull consuming all memory until memory realloc failed message · Issue #2840 · git\-lfs/git\-lfs · GitHub|https://github.com/git-lfs/git-lfs/issues/2840]
[Memory allocation problems when cloning repository with LFS objects largen than available RAM #3524|https://github.com/git-lfs/git-lfs/issues/3524]

h3. Workaround
* Create script task
* In script, implement the work around mentioned in [Memory allocation problems when cloning repository with LFS objects largen than available RAM #3524|https://github.com/git-lfs/git-lfs/issues/3524].

h3. Suggested fix
Implement large file option flag in Git checkout tasks to have Git checkout task use the work around in [Memory allocation problems when cloning repository with LFS objects largen than available RAM #3524|https://github.com/git-lfs/git-lfs/issues/3524] in a way that is transparent to the users.
fields.summary: Git LFS issue causes system OOM errors when file is larger than system RAM

fields.description:
Each plan and branch should have the option to track revision and Build status by git tree hash not commit hash.  This way if a commit is merged to several branches, and the commit message is not used by the build, only one build is done for the tree.

If the commit does not relate to the files that are built, but if no files change the binaries will be identical, the build should be tracked by the tree and not the commit hash.  The commit hash and commit message can change with a force push.  But the tree hash will only change when any files changes.  This option tracks to the build artifacts much closer then the commit hash in this case.

Here is a standard commit message:
{noformat}
$ git cat-file -p 2cfe7c3fcf3c1bdddf595c01ddc4a8c6ba7864e9
tree e22ca8d045d076bbf307dc1a15bbd12bb162956e
parent c56aee5bfee6135735cf47326f0c237fdfc19352
parent 2ccc6a9ebb5ad22de6a6b77d86e0b6441d1b8607
author dave laser <dlaser@atlassian.com> 1639781568 +0000
committer dave laser <dlaser@atlassian.com> 1639781568 +0000

Pull request #4: ...
{noformat} 

Option to track revision e22ca8d0, tree, not 2cfe7c3f, commit hash.

h3. Expected Results
An option to report build revision by tree and not commit hash.  If two commits have the same tree, the build status is reported without the build being run and all links go back to the original build showing both commits.

h3. Actual Results
Each commit can get a build.  Separate commits with the same tree, and possibly the same binaries, will have separate builds and different revisions.  The status reported back will be linked by commit message not tree.
fields.summary: Build status should be tracked by git tree hash not commit hash

fields.description:
h3. Problem

Git checkout tasks are extremely slow when done via the Source Code Checkout task through BAMBOO-SSH-PROXY
h3. Environment

Bamboo 8.0.4 or later (apache-sshd-2.7.0+). Earlier releases which use apache-sshd-1.7.0 are not prone to this issue.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

Add a large repository to your Linked Repositories in Bamboo (4GB+, _mysql-server_ for example)

Create a code checkout task in a Plan

Run the plan and observe the '{_}git fetch{_}' low throughput.
h3. Expected Results

The _git fetch_ command throughput via BAMBOO-SSH-PROXY should be equivalent or really close the similar git command when reaching the target repository directly without a proxy.
h3. Actual Results

Git checkout via the BAMBOO-SSH-PROXY from a remote agent or local agent is extremely slow (up to 2 or 3Mb/s maximum). Taking a considerable amount of time to complete any checkout task.
{noformat}
simple  18-Dec-2021 05:08:16    Receiving objects:  38% (49055/127204), 279.71 MiB | 1.21 MiB/s
simple  18-Dec-2021 05:08:17    Receiving objects:  39% (49610/127204), 280.36 MiB | 1.21 MiB/s
simple  18-Dec-2021 05:08:17    Receiving objects:  39% (50100/127204), 281.02 MiB | 1.22 MiB/s
simple  18-Dec-2021 05:08:18    Receiving objects:  39% (50730/127204), 282.33 MiB | 1.21 MiB/s{noformat}
h3. Workaround
h4. *Enable Repository caching* on agents and possibly {*}Shallow clones{*}.
 * Bamboo Administration -> Linked Repositories -> Select the repository -> Advanced Options -> Enable repository caching on Agents

You can also enable [*Use shallow clones*|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo0800/git-1077778658.html#:~:text=Use%20shallow%20clones,enabled%20by%20default.] if your builds don't depend on the repository history. That option is right below "Enable repository caching".

Enabling the two options above will speed up things considerably from the second time the build runs on the same agent. The agent needs to check out the full repository at least once so it can have a full copy of it.

Note: If applying this workaround, make sure not to delete any of the relevant git repository caches that are stored locally on the agent, otherwise, a full checkout will be performed again via the BAMBOO-SSH-PROXY (slower).

 

And/or:
h4. Checkout source code as a Script task

You can optionally check out the source code as a regular "git" command within a Script task. This will bypass BAMBOO-SSH-PROXY and speed up things. You will need to configure git authentication manually on each agent.
{code:bash}
#!/bin/bash -x
# Your remote/local agent must have proper SSH keys exchanged with your Git repository
# This script will not manage authentication

# This code is untested and may need further adjustments to suit your requirements
# Use this script only if after finding that enabling Repository Caching on your repositories 
# does not suit you
REPOSITORY=${bamboo.planRepository.repositoryUrl}
REVISION=${bamboo.planRepository.revision}
BRANCHNAME=${bamboo.planRepository.branchName}
GIT=${bamboo.capability.system.git.executable}
GIT_SSH_COMMAND="ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o BatchMode=yes -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null"

${GIT} init
${GIT} config remote.origin.url >&- || ${GIT} remote add origin ${REPOSITORY}

# [0] = REVISION
# [1] = Branch/HEAD
CUSTOM_GIT_HEADS=($(${GIT} ls-remote --heads ${REPOSITORY}))

${GIT} fetch ${REPOSITORY} +${CUSTOM_GIT_HEADS[1]}:${CUSTOM_GIT_HEADS[1]} --update-head-ok --progress --verbose
${GIT} show-ref ${BRANCHNAME}

# When specific revision is requested via custom build or rerun
if [ ${CUSTOM_GIT_HEADS[0]} != ${REVISION} ] ; then
  ${GIT} checkout -f ${REVISION}
else
  ${GIT} checkout -f ${BRANCHNAME}
fi
{code}
fields.summary: Slow git source code checkout from Bamboo remote or local agent via BAMBOO-SSH-PROXY

h3. Issue Summary

When a VCS checkout task fails, Bamboo attempts to recover. If the Force clean build option the retry fails on a Cleaned source directory.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a checkout task

h3. Expected Results

Bamboo retries the checkout task, and tries to recover
h3. Actual Results

When Bamboo retries the task, if the build directory is cleaned before running git fetch, the error {{fatal: not a git repository}} is logged
{noformat}
error	19-Nov-2021 14:41:05	Checkout to revision 18cc82f87bb9e6535d12e33ca3ee408769e8c242 has failed.
simple	19-Nov-2021 14:41:05	'C:/Program Files/Git/bin/git.exe' remote set-url origin ssh://git@git.ncipher.com:7999/nshield/main.git
simple	19-Nov-2021 14:41:05	Warning: failed to checkout source code to directory 'C:\Users\bamboo-agent\bamboo-agent-home\xml-data\build-dir\NC-MAIN02-WIN64REL\main', trying to recover...

 {noformat}
h3. Workaround

fields.description:
h2. Problem

Currently, the *[Using Plan Branches|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/using-plan-branches-289276872.html]* documentation >> *Automatic branch management* >> *When pull request is created* doesn't mention that, if an *App Password* is being used, it needs to have the "Pull Request Read" permission on Bitbucket Cloud side. If this permission is not set for the App Password, Bamboo will not be able to read the pull request information, and therefore won't be able to create the branch.
h2. Solution

Update the table under "Automatic branch management" to include that information.
!image-2021-12-10-11-37-50-711.png|width=531,height=503!
fields.summary: Documentation improvement

fields.description:
h2. Problem

When adding a Bitbucket Cloud repository to Bamboo, it's possible to have Bamboo automatically create new plan branches whenever a pull request is created in Bitbucket Cloud.

However, if using an [App Password|https://support.atlassian.com/bitbucket-cloud/docs/app-passwords/] to connect Bamboo to BBCloud, the App Password is required to have the *Pull Request Read* permission in Bitbucket Cloud side (see below) in order for this to work. In case this permission is missing, Bamboo will not be able to authenticate agains BBCloud to read the Pull Request information, and therefore, will not be able to create the branch.

!image-2021-12-10-11-21-09-374.png|width=286,height=346!
h2. Suggestion

Bamboo should either check the App Password permissions in BBCloud and warn the user in case the Pull Request read permission is not set, or there should be a message in the *Branch Configuration page* to inform users that this strategy of branch plan creation requires such permission.

The warning could be presented here:
!image-2021-12-10-11-24-35-370.png|width=553,height=178!
fields.summary: Bamboo & Bitbucket Cloud: Pull Request Branch Creation should warn about required permissions

fields.description:
h3. Current Situation

Bamboo currently allows the following options for automatic branch plan creation:
# Manually
# When pull request is created
# When new branch in repository is created
# When new branch in repository is created and matches expression 

Only one option can be selected at the same time. 

h3. Accepted solution
Option 2 (*When pull request is created*) could be simultaneously enabled with either 3 (*When new branch in repository is created*) or 4 (*When new branch in repository is created and matches expression*)
fields.summary: Allow multiple automatic branch creation options simultaneously

h3. Issue Summary

[https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo-specs-docs] provides a list of legacy specs references. Documentation links for newer releases are not provided on that page leading to confusion about whether they are available or not.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Access [https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo-specs-docs]
 # Noticed that the directory list only covers Specs up to 6.2.3 + the latest

h3. Expected Results

Either:
 * An updated directory list of references Specs x Bamboo versions
 * A well-formed template page/style with links for every Bamboo Specs release available.

h3. Actual Results

Reference links are only provided for Bamboo Specs up to 6.2.3
h3. Workaround

Access the required documentation by reaching to:
 * [https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo-specs-docs/x.y.z]
 * Where (x.y.z) equals to the Bamboo version
fields.summary: Fix directory listing in https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo-specs-docs

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When configuring an external directory and clicking *Synchronize* to trigger a manual synchronization, the message _Synchronising…_ is shown indefinitely.
 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Add an external user directory to Bamboo
 # Access the user directories page
 # Trigger a manual synchronization by clicking the button *Synchronize*

h3. Expected Results

A message showing that the synchronization completed successfully is shown

h3. Actual Results

The user directory remains in state _Synchronizing ..._ indefinitely and the below error is seen in the developer console:

 !image-2021-12-03-17-46-27-417.png|thumbnail! 
h3. Workaround

The synchronization is actually triggered in the backend. Refresh the page and you'll see a message stating when and if the synchronization completed successfully.

 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Manual synchronizing of user directories hangs on the UI

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When a user creates a Bitbucket Server or Data Center repository configuration ssh keys are automatically created by Bamboo and the public ssh key uploaded to Bitbucket. In short, if the user has permissions to manage the repository in Bitbucket, the public key will be added to the repository. However, if the user doesn't have permissions to manage the repository (only to access it) the public key will be added to his/ her own profile under *Manage account > SSH keys* in Bitbucket.

If the public key gets added to the user profile this might become a problem when that user is deactivated (i.e. user showing up as {{UNLICENSED}}) or deleted from Bitbucket. If the public key is not accessible anymore because the user is not available, Bamboo will fail to communicate to Bitbucket using that ssh key pair.

A Bamboo admin could reach out to the user and ask them to remove the public key from their user account, and then re-save the repository configuration in Bamboo to add a new public key to the repository. The problem is that right now there's no way for a Bamboo admin to know that a certain repository configuration has its public key stored under someone's user account in Bitbucket and not the repository from the Bamboo UI. 

h3. Suggested Solution

Add a warning message inside the repository configuration in Bamboo to let Bamboo admins know that the repository has its public key under someone's user account in Bitbucket and that this might cause problems in the future in case that user account ever gets deactivated or deleted. This should prompt Bamboo admins to follow-up with the user who created the repository configuration so they can work together and promote the public key to the repository. Here's an example:

# Bamboo admin opens a plan-level repository configuration in Bamboo and sees a warning message reporting that the public key was stored under *userA*'s account in Bitbucket.
# Bamboo admins follow-up with *userA* and asks the user to remove that repository's public key from his/ her account.
# *userA* removes the public key -- repository configuration will now report the following error inside Bamboo:
!Screenshot 2021-12-03 at 13.39.47.png|thumbnail!
# Bamboo admin re-saves the repository configuration forcing Bamboo to generate a new ssh key pair and add the public key to the repository in Bitbucket.
# From this moment on the public key is no longer associated to *userA* in Bitbucket so deactivating or deleting the user account won't prevent Bamboo from accessing the repository in Bitbucket.

{panel:title=|borderStyle=dashed|borderWidth=2px|borderColor=#6a8eb3|titleBGColor=#f8f8f8|bgColor=#f8f8f8}
The user may have several public keys under his/ her user account. In order to identify the public key from the repository configuration you're viewing in Bamboo just expand the *Advanced options* and search for _"Public key generated for this repository"_:

!Screenshot 2021-12-03 at 11.57.48.png|thumbnail!

{panel}
fields.summary: Warn Bamboo admins when repository ssh keys are stored under a user account in Bitbucket Server or Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When a user creates a Bitbucket Server or Data Center repository configuration ssh keys are automatically created by Bamboo and the public ssh key uploaded to Bitbucket. In short, if the user has permissions to manage the repository in Bitbucket, the public key will be added to the repository. However, if the user doesn't have permissions to manage the repository (only to access it) the public key will be added to his/ her own profile under *Manage account > SSH keys* in Bitbucket.

If the public key gets added to the user profile this might become a problem when that user is deactivated (i.e. user showing up as {{UNLICENSED}}) or deleted from Bitbucket. If the public key is not accessible anymore because the user is not available, Bamboo will fail to communicate to Bitbucket using that ssh key pair.

When a Bamboo admin attempts to re-save the repository configuration in an attempt to avoid running into this problem and change the location of the keys nothing happens. The location of the key does not change.

h3. Suggested Solution

Allow Bamboo admins to re-save the repository configuration and change the location of the ssh keys in Bitbucket Server or Data Center to avoid problems accessing the repository if the user eventually gets disabled or deleted from Bitbucket. Since the public key location will change to the repository it will no longer be associated to a specific user account -- so changes to that account will not affect the public key and the communication between Bamboo and Bitbucket for that repository.
 
h3. Workaround

Ask the user who saved the repository configuration to remove the public key from his/ her user account in Bitbucket under the *Manage account > SSH keys* page so that you (as a Bamboo admin) can re-save the configuration and change the location where the public key is stored.

{panel:title=|borderStyle=dashed|borderWidth=2px|borderColor=#6a8eb3|titleBGColor=#f8f8f8|bgColor=#f8f8f8}
The user may have several public keys under his/ her user account. In order to identify the public key from the repository configuration you're viewing in Bamboo just expand the *Advanced options* and search for _"Public key generated for this repository"_:

!Screenshot 2021-12-03 at 11.57.48.png|thumbnail!

{panel}
fields.summary: Allow Bamboo admins to re-save the repository configuration and change the location where the ssh keys are stored in Bitbucket Server or Data Center

fields.description:
As it stands right now, it is hard to tell what the latest version of the Bamboo YAML specs are, and what other versions exist (higher or lower).

Google searches for "latest version of bamboo specs reference" return the [6.9 spec documentation|https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo-specs-docs/6.9.0/specs.html] at the top of the search results, and from there there is no way to tell if there is something newer available.

Perhaps put some kind of an indication on each of the Bamboo Specs documentation pages that let's the user know that they are either on the latest version of the document, or not.

Additionally, take the following pages for bamboo specs of different versions:
 * [https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo0700/bamboo-specs-1014682894.html]
 * [https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo0702/bamboo-specs-1031180127.html]
 * [https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo0609/bamboo-specs]

All of these pages are ostensibly related to different Bamboo Server versions, but the links on it don't take you to the correct specs documentation- in fact, they all take you to 8.0.4 documentation (latest), with no way to actually find the version of Bamboo Specs reference that you're looking for.

[https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo-specs-docs/] <- that would seem to be a list of versions of bamboo specs, as well, but it's not correct or complete.
fields.summary: Surface better versioning and fix documentation version issues related to Bamboo Specs

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Bamboo does not run the export in a Windows environment.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Install Bamboo in a Windows environment with the default home and shared directories
 # Go to *System >> Export* and run the export

h3. Expected Results

Bamboo should export the instance without showing any issues.
h3. Actual Results

Bamboo shows the following error message:
{code:java}
Specified file name must be a relative path under Bamboo home directory.
{code}
h3. !bamboo_Error_ScreenShot.PNG|width=502,height=316!
h3. Workaround
 # Stop Bamboo
 # Add the JVM argument *-Dbamboo.paths.set.allowed=true* to your [System Properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/configuring-your-system-properties-289277345.html].
 # Manually create the <bamboo-home>\shared\exports folder
 # Start Bamboo back
 # Run the export again
fields.summary: Bamboo does not run the export in a Windows environment

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

As for now, it's possible to select three different variable scopes when configuring the "Version Variable Incrementer" task in Bamboo:
 
 * +Local scoped variables+ are {*}only available inside the same job{*}. Next jobs, stages, or deployments will retain the original value defined at the very beginning of the build.
 * +Result scope variables+ will be *available in the current job and passed into subsequent stages* or related deployment releases. Next runs will use the value defined in the plan configuration.
 * +Plan scoped variables+ will be available from the {*}next run of the build{*}, and it will reflect in the build configuration; it will not affect the currently running build or its deployments.

h3. Suggested Solution

 
In some scenarios, it might be needed to use the updated value of the variable on later stages/jobs of the same plan (Result scope variables) *and* subsequent builds (Plan scoped variables). For these types of scenarios, it would be nice to be able to select multiple options at the task configuration or to have a separate option covering this requirement.
h3. Workaround

Use the "[Inject Bamboo variables|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/configuring-a-variables-task-687213475.html]" task that allows reading the current values from variables, and create new "ephemeral" build scoped variables that can be used in subsequent stages
fields.summary: Variable scope for the "Version Variable Incrementer" task should allow selecting multiple options
REST API endpoint /rest/api/latest/search/branches does not provide all fields

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The [upgrade documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/bamboo-upgrade-guide-720411366.html] is misleading people to follow more steps than necessary and therefor not being able to complete the upgrade as it should.

When following the full guide, here are the steps at the full procedure, in summary.
 * Stop Bamboo
 * Backup Bamboo configuration
 * Follow the link to Linux install instructions which has the steps:
 ** Download Bamboo
 ** Create the installation directory
 ** *Create the new home directory ( and point your Bamboo to that new directory)*
 ** *Start Bamboo*
 ** *Configure Bamboo*
 * Come back to the Bamboo upgrade page
 * Point your Bamboo-home to your original bamboo-home folder
 * At this point, if you haven't performed an upgrade before, your instance will not have your old data as it will not be pointing to your original bamboo-home-folder and it won't start.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to [upgrade documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/bamboo-upgrade-guide-720411366.html]
 # Start following the guide to upgrade Bamboo
 # At step +_2. Download and install a new Bamboo instance_+ it will ask you to choose the OS and then click on the link to install a new Bamboo. Chose Linux.  !Screen Shot 2021-11-30 at 1.27.43 PM.png|width=456,height=357!
 # Note that even though there is a text saying that {_}this upgrade scenario uses the home directory and the external database of the original Bamboo instance{_}, it will get confusing.
 # There is a link to another page [Linux install instructions|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/installing-bamboo-on-linux-289276792.html]. At this point, the instructions at the Linux installation page are for a new Bamboo instance, so it does not mention that you should point your bamboo-home directory to your original bamboo-home directory at all in that guide. Instead it makes you create a new directory as you can see here.
 # If you follow the whole guide and then you come back to the upgrade page, you will have already pointed your bamboo-home to a new home directory and started Bamboo at least once without using your original Bamboo folder.  !Screen Shot 2021-11-30 at 1.34.59 PM.png|width=515,height=313!

h3. Solution 

Instead of linking a page at step +_2. Download and install a new Bamboo instance_+ at the upgrade page, place the steps directly in the upgrade guide. So when you open the Linux arrow, you should see the actual steps in there and not a link to another page.

The upgrade page should contain all the steps within the page to perform the upgrade for all OS.

This would generate less confusion to new people performing upgrades, specially since the CVE was out and we had a great increase of tickets about upgrades to 8.x.
fields.summary: Bamboo upgrade documentation is misleading

h3. Issue Summary

When plan's TagTrigger configured by Bamboo Specs it ignores conditions
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 * Create Bamboo Specs project and add TagTrigger to any plan

{code:java}
...
new TagTrigger().filter(".*")
     .conditions(new PlansGreenTriggerCondition()
        .plans(new PlanIdentifier("PROJ", "PLAN")))
...
{code}
 * Run Maven command to publish plan to Bamboo Server

h3. Expected Results

Plan has Tag trigger with provided condition.
h3. Actual Results

Plan has Tag trigger without provided condition.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Tag trigger conditions can't be configured by Bamboo Specs

h3. Issue Summary

Calling _deploy/dashboard/paginate_ endpoint (eg. by accessing deployment dashboard) can result in significant memory consumption and garbage collection
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create 1000 environments
 # Call _deploy/dashboard/paginate_ as an anonymous user:

{code:java}
curl -X GET "http://<BAMBOO_URL>/bamboo/rest/api/latest/deploy/dashboard/paginate?limit=100" {code}

h3. Expected Results

Bamboo doesn't load into memory environments that the user can't access 
h3. Actual Results

Bamboo tries to load all 1000 environments into memory at once
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behaviour. A workaround will be added here when available

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The wrapper shipped with remote agents is not working in FreeBSD.

{panel:title=|borderStyle=dashed|borderWidth=2px|borderColor=#1663A7|titleBGColor=#A0CCF3| bgColor=#f9ffff}
This was tested against FreeBSD *11.4* only but it may affect other versions of FreeBSD.
{panel}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Set up a FreeBSD server.
 # Download the remote agent jar file to the FreeBSD server.
 # Install the agent using the command shown under the _"Running a remote agent"_ section of the *Bamboo administration > Agents > Install remote agent* page:
{noformat}
java -jar atlassian-bamboo-agent-installer-8.0.4.jar http://bamboo.baseurl/agentServer/
{noformat}

h3. Expected Results

Both remote agent and wrapper start up.
h3. Actual Results

This is the message that shows up right when trying to start the agent with the command mentioned above:

{noformat}
Reinstalling wrapper binaries, reason: agent either not installed or outdated
WARNING: Unknown OS: FreeBSD
Bamboo agent will run in fail fast mode.  If the Bamboo server goes down,
the agent will need to be restarted.
Agent wrapper won't be installed - no files to install
Installing file: /generic/lib/bamboo-agent-bootstrap-jar-with-dependencies.jar to: /home/ec2-user/remote-agent-home/lib/bamboo-agent-bootstrap.jar
Unzipping /classpath.zip to /home/ec2-user/remote-agent-home/classpath
Could not find source file /classpath.zip
Agent installed
...
{noformat}

 * The remote agent does start up *but* there's no wrapper running.
 * If you run {{ps}} to list the current running processes you'll not find the wrapper there.
 * There are no files inside the <agent-home>/bin and <agent-home>/conf folders.
 * Since there's no wrapper it won't be possible to modify the <agent-home>/conf/wrapper.conf file to make adjustments to the heap size or any other Java properties. You'll need to add those properties to the agent installation command.
 * Since there's no <agent-home>/bin/bamboo-agent.sh file you'll not be able to start/ stop the agent. You'd have to stop the agent by killing the process with {{kill -9}} or requesting an agent shutdown from the *Bamboo administration > Agents* page (using the _"Request agent stop"_ button inside the agent summary page). You'll need to restart the agent by continuously issuing the installation command pointing to the existing <agent-home> folder.
* Since there's no wrapper there's no way to configure the agent to try and automatically reconnect to Bamboo in case it loses connection to Bamboo for an extended period of time (e.g. planned maintenance). You'll have to manually restart the agent.

h3. Notes

If you try installing the agent using a jar file from Bamboo 7.x (e.g. agent-installer-7.2.6.jar) against your Bamboo 8.x instance the behaviour is a little different. The agent wrapper installation seems to take place. There's no warning about the wrapper not getting installed in the agent logs. If you check the <agent-home>/bin and   <agent-home>/conf folders files will be there *however* the wrapper will not startup. This may be a bit misleading as you'll think the wrapper is working *but it is not*. Therefore changes made to the <agent-home>/conf/wrapper.conf will not take effect. If you try to start the agent using <agent-home>/bin/bamboo-agent.sh you will get the following errors:

{noformat}
$ ./bamboo-agent.sh start
Unable to locate any of the following binaries:
  /usr/home/ec2-user/remote-agent-home/bin/./wrapper-freebsd-x86-64
  /usr/home/ec2-user/remote-agent-home/bin/./wrapper-freebsd-x86-32
  /usr/home/ec2-user/remote-agent-home/bin/./wrapper
{noformat}

h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Remote agent wrapper is not working in FreeBSD

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Bamboo Enable webhooks documentation contains outdated information that needs to be updated

There are also other webhooks that could possibly be added to the page.
 *  [Enabling webhooks|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/enabling-webhooks-946626050.html]

h3. Steps to Reproduce

This page relates only to RSS enabled webhooks, but it is not explicit about that. Customers may look for traditional webhook information on this page and get confused by it.

The documentation also provides wrong commands to be followed.
h3. Expected Results

{color:#ff0000}Wrong working instruction:{color}
 * *_In the top navigation bar, click Create > Create Bamboo Specs._*

This option doesn't exist in Bamboo (tested on 7 and 8), please point it to the right path:
h3. Actual Results

{color:#FF0000}Correct working instruction:{color}
 * *_In the top navigation bar, click Specs > Setup Specs Repository._*

{color:#ff0000}Add a concise context:{color}

This page relates only to RSS enabled webhooks, but it is not explicit about that. Customers may look for traditional webhook information on this page and get confused by it.

It would also be important to add a link that would refer to the traditional PLAN triggering API call. E.g:
 * {{https://<BAMBOO_URL>/rest/triggers/latest/remote/changeDetection?planKey=<PLAN-KEY>}}

h3. Workaround

Perhaps mixing the following Docs/KBs into a single article would with distinct RSS and non-RSS sessions make more sense:
 * [Repository triggers the build when changes are committed|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/repository-triggers-the-build-when-changes-are-committed-289276902.html] 
 * [Git repository remote trigger|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamkb/git-repository-remote-trigger-859500786.html]
fields.summary: Update Bamboo Enable Webhooks page

fields.description:
[Bamboo remote agent installation guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/bamboo-remote-agent-installation-guide-289276832.html]

Since it's possible to install multiple agents in the same machine, our installation guide currently has a warning stating that we need to indicate different *home directories* for each agent.

Considering agents also have a {*}temporary directory{*}, it would be great if we updated the documentation to mention that as well, since multiple agents sharing the same temporary directory can lead to some issues.

The temporary directory can be configured through [these steps|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamkb/how-to-configure-temporary-directory-in-bamboo-remote-agent-1055953756.html]

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create plan A with key PRJ-PLANA.
 # Create plan branch which has a key PRJ-PLANA0
 # Create plan B with trigger 
 # Add condition "Only run Build if other Plans are currently passing" and provide key PRJ-PLANA0

Configuration is saved and used for trigger condition.

Validation error

PLANBRANCH-KEY is a job and can not be used in this field.
{code}

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Artifacts from private repositories are not download by Java Specs scan, this is because Bamboo does not use the maven repositories element added in Java Specs *pom.xml* file.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create multiple build plan Java Specs
 # Use artifacts present in private maven repository
 # Add repositories element to the Specs configuration *pom.xml*
 # Trigger a spec scan

h3. Expected Results

The custom artifacts are downloaded from the private maven repository *pom.xml* and Specs Scan is successful.
h3. Actual Results

Specs Scan fails
{noformat}
19-Oct-2021 08:57:46	    <pluginRepositories>
19-Oct-2021 08:57:46	        <pluginRepository>
19-Oct-2021 08:57:46	            <id>central</id>
...
19-Oct-2021 08:57:46	            <url>http://repositories/</url>
19-Oct-2021 08:57:46	        </pluginRepository>
19-Oct-2021 08:57:46	    </pluginRepositories>
.....
19-Oct-2021 08:57:50	[INFO] BUILD FAILURE
19-Oct-2021 08:57:50	[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
19-Oct-2021 08:57:50	[INFO] Total time:  2.153 s
19-Oct-2021 08:57:50	[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
19-Oct-2021 08:57:50	[ERROR] Failed to execute goal on project bamboo-specs-generator: Could not resolve dependencies for project com.atlassian.bamboo:bamboo-specs-generator:jar:1.0.0: Could not find artifact artifact.name in central (http://repositories/) -> [Help 1]
 {noformat}
h3. Workaround

Add the repositories element to _BAMBOO_INSTALL/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/classes/bamboo-specs-pom.xml_
fields.summary: Java Specs scan should recognize private maven repositories element in pom.xml

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Builds from plans that are linked to Subversion repositories stay queued forever when *triggered automatically* (e.g. repository polling) based on code changes whereas *manual* builds work just fine.

Since builds triggered automatically stay queued they'll eventually get terminated by Bamboo so you should start seeing a lot of the following messages from the Bamboo UI and inside the <bamboo-home>/logs/atlassian-bamboo.log file:

{noformat}
2021-11-22 10:16:42,757 INFO [scheduler_Worker-1] [OrphanedBuildMonitorJob] PROJ-SUB-JOB1-2 marked as Queued but not present in queue since Mon Nov 22 10:03:42 UTC 2021
2021-11-22 10:16:42,758 ERROR [scheduler_Worker-1] [OrphanedBuildMonitorJob] Build PROJ-SUB-JOB1-2 had to be cancelled: it was marked as queued but was not present in the queue for (at least) the past 720 seconds.
{noformat}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a plan and link it to a Subversion repository.
# Make sure there's at least one trigger inside the plan (e.g. repository polling, remote trigger and etc). I'd suggest using repository polling since this doesn't require any additional setup compared to the remote trigger.
# Make changes to your Subversion repository and wait for Bamboo to trigger the build.

h3. Expected Results

The agent starts building and checking out code from the Subversion repository.

h3. Actual Results

From the Bamboo logs we can see that the application finds code changes and dispatches the build to the agent:

{noformat}
2021-11-22 10:02:51,236 INFO [10-BAM::PlanExec:pool-16-thread-2] [ChangeDetectionListenerAction] : Change detection found 1 change for plan PROJ-SUB
2021-11-22 10:02:51,385 INFO [10-BAM::PlanExec:pool-16-thread-2] [ChainExecutionManagerImpl] Build PROJ-SUB-JOB1-2 has been dispatched
2021-11-22 10:02:51,389 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-11] [BuildQueueManagerImpl] Attempting to queue Project - SVN - Default Job #2 (PROJ-SUB-JOB1-2).
2021-11-22 10:02:51,390 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-11] [ExecutionPhaseServiceImpl] Project - SVN - Default Job #2 (PROJ-SUB-JOB1-2) queued
2021-11-22 10:02:51,424 INFO [20-BAM::Default Agent::Agent:pool-34-thread-1] [BuildAgentControllerImpl] Agent 393217 checking build queue for executables...
2021-11-22 10:02:51,425 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-11] [BuildQueueManagerImpl] Sent ExecutableQueueUpdate: addToQueue, agents known to be affected: []
2021-11-22 10:02:51,448 INFO [ActiveMQ Session Task-4] [BuildQueueManagerImpl] Sending PROJ-SUB-JOB1-2 to agent 192.168.0.100 (id: 2457601, REMOTE, online, enabled)
2021-11-22 10:02:51,449 INFO [ActiveMQ Session Task-4] [ExecutionPhaseServiceImpl] Project - SVN - Default Job #2 (PROJ-SUB-JOB1-2) sent to agent 2457601
2021-11-22 10:02:51,449 INFO [ActiveMQ Session Task-4] [CurrentlyBuildingContainer] startBuildingOnAgent called for [PROJ-SUB-JOB1-2], agent 2457601
{noformat}

However, the agent reports an error and does NOT start the build. The following exception can be seen inside the <agent-home>/atlassian-bamboo-agent.log file:

{noformat}
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2021/11/22 11:02:51 | 2021-11-22 11:02:51,477 ERROR [0-BAM::192.168.0.100::Agent:pool-3-thread-1] [BuildAgentControllerImpl] Unknown exception occurred on '192.168.0.100'. Agent will attempt to recover its normal operation...

fields.description:
*Background*

We have installed the bamboo agent and are using systemd to manage the service. However, we need to be able to have the build and deploy jobs running via the bamboo agent on this Linux host to authenticate and deploy files to a separate Windows host with DFS shares.

To accomplish this, the best solution we've found is to wrap k5start around the {{bamboo-agent.sh}} script by modifying the systemd service file. This then allows us to use keytabs to run the bamboo agent as a service account and authenticate to a Windows DFS share that has granted that service account permissions.

*The Problem*

While working on the solution above, one of the issues we ran into is that by default the bamboo agent has the {{wrapper.daemonize}} property set to {{TRUE}} within the {{bamboo-agent.sh}} script. As a result, this will cause the bamboo agent to fork and break its ability to be wrapped in a k5start script.

*Our Solution*

We've been able to get this working by modifying the bamboo-agent.sh script from the service file as you see below.
{code:java}
ExecStartPre=/usr/bin/sed -i -e 's/ wrapper\.daemonize=TRUE / wrapper.daemonize=FALSE /g' /opt/bamboo-agent/bin/bamboo-agent.sh {code}
What the above does is that just before systemd launches the ExecStart command, it uses sed to ensure that any instance of {{wrapper.daemonize=TRUE}} in the {{bamboo-agent.sh}} script is changed to {{{}wrapper.daemonize=FALSE{}}}. That tells {{/opt/bamboo-agent/bin/wrapper}} to not fork, so the wrapper script never exits, which is what we want.

We'd like to request that the {{bamboo-agent.sh}} script be updated to provide a way to control whether the  {{wrapper.daemonize}} property is set to TRUE/FALSE?
fields.summary: Bamboo agent should provide mechanism to not daemonize

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

YAML Specs extends YAML with the {{!include 'file'}} tag. The include tag expands to the content of the file where it is placed. If the YAML files contain permission, the Specs scan will fail.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 #  Define multiple YAML Spec files, which contains plan permission e.g. {{*plan1.yml* and *plan2.yml*}}
 # Include the files in {{bamboo.yml}} file
{code:java}
---
!include 'plan1.yml'
---
!include 'plan2.yml'
{code}

h3. Expected Results

Multiple plans should be created on Specs scan
h3. Actual Results

Scan fails, with only one plan created, with error in log
{noformat}
 Invalid format of the YAML file: expected a single document in the stream
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

Define each plan permission in the main {{bamboo.yml}} file, and not in each plan YAML file
{code:java}
---
!include 'plan1.yml'
---
!include 'plan2.yml'

---
version: 2
plan: PROJECT-PLAN1

plan-permissions:
  - users: admin
    permissions:
      - admin
  - roles: logged-in
    permissions:
      - view

---
version: 2
plan: PROJECT-PLAN2

plan-permissions:
  - users:
      - admin
    permissions:
      - view
    - roles: logged-in
    permissions:
      - view {code}
fields.summary: YAML Spec scan fails if the include tag files contains permission definition

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When an Enhanced Plan Branch is {*}_disabled_{*}, any changes to the linked branch should not trigger a build. But when a commit is placed to the Specs codebase, Bamboo triggers a build on that Spec Plan to "refresh". After the "refresh" build is over, Plan Branch remains "Enabled" and any other commits to regular code in the repository will trigger a build, breaking its original disabled state.

The Plan branch remains in a _disabled_ state when the commit is not related to the Specs codebase.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Use Enhanced Plan Branches
 # Disable a specific Plan Branch
 # Push any changes to the Specs codebase for that Plan Branch
 # Observe Bamboo enabling the Plan and running it
 # Bamboo leaves the Plan Branch enabled

h3. Expected Results

When a Plan Branch is disabled, Bamboo should completely ignore any trigger changes to the plan, including changes to the Specs codebase.
h3. Actual Results

Bamboo triggers a build on the Plan branch and leaves the Plan in an Enabled state
h3. Workaround

None
h3. Security Implication

A developer with Repository access but with no Bamboo access can trigger a "dummy" build by making a change to the Specs codebase, enabling the Plan branch and exposing information from it.

Customers may disable a specific Plan branch and rely on external triggers that would build that Plan at specific times of the day. If a commit is made out of those boundaries, the Plan may run and cause unpredictable results.
fields.summary: Disabled Enhanced Plan Branches are Enabled when a commit to Specs is pushed
